creator: brobinson@hp.com
text:
The DoInit1Test servlet tests that an HTTP 500 error code is sent back when a 
request is made for it.  When the UnavailableException is thrown out, our 
container does not put the servlet in our servlet pool, and requests for it 
result in an HTTP 404.  This is legitimate behavior as far as I can tell, as 
the servlet's servie() method is never called, which is what the test is 
testing for.

I would suggest modifying GTest so that multiple error codes can be accepted as 
legitimate results.

creator: gregw@mortbay.org
text:
The Jetty WWW server handles an UnavailableException by returning
a 503 Service Unavailable exception, which is perfectly valid
response.

creator: Ryan.Lubke@Sun.COM
text:
Tomcat also returns a 503.  

In regards to a 404 being returned to denote permanent unavailablity of a
servlet.  503 would seem to make more sense in this case.

   "The server is currently unable to handle the request due to a
    temporary overloading or maintenance of the server. The implication
    is that this is a temporary condition which will be alleviated after
    some delay. If known, the length of the delay may be indicated in a
    Retry-After header.  If no Retry-After is given, the client SHOULD
    handle the response as it would for a 500 response."

However, since the spec doesn't explicitly state that a 503 should be returned
in the case of permanent unavailablity, the test should probably be excluded
until the spec is clarified at a later date.
